urn:contentItem:60XN-9371-JBVR-32YY-00000-00California braces for power shutoffs and warm, windy weekend2020-09-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:24ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONALCalifornia braces for power shutoffs and warm, windy weekendDaisy NguyenThe Associated Press

SAN FRANCISCO - Firefighters and officials at California's largest utility company braced for hot, dry and windy weather in northern and central areas of the state this weekend that may fan the flames of several major wildfires or ignite new ones.

Pacific Gas & Electric warned Friday it may cut power from Sunday morning to Monday, potentially affecting 97,000 customers in 16 counties, during which forecasters said a ridge of high pressure will raise temperatures and generate gusts flowing from the interior to the coast.

PG&E initially warned that approximately 21,000 customers in three counties would lose power beginning Saturday evening but expanded the potential shutoff when the forecast changed.

The utility is tracking the weather to determine if it would be necessary to shut off power to areas where gusts could damage the company's equipment or hurl debris into lines that can ignite flammable vegetation.

When heavy winds were predicted earlier this month, PG&E cut power to about 167,000 homes and businesses in central and Northern California in a more targeted approach after being criticized last year for acting too broadly when it blacked out 2 million customers to prevent fires.

PG&E equipment has sparked past large wildfires, including the 2018 fire that destroyed much of the Sierra foothills town of Paradise and killed 85 people.

Firefighters battling the state's largest wildfire braced for the change in weather by constructing fuel breaks on Friday to keep the flames from reaching a marijuana-growing enclave where authorities said many of the locals have refused to evacuate and abandon their maturing crops.

The wildfire called the August Complex is nearing the small communities of Post Mountain and Trinity Pines, about 200 miles (322 kilometres) northwest of Sacramento, the Los Angeles Times reported.

Law enforcement officers went door to door warning of the encroaching fire danger but could not force residents to evacuate, Trinity County Sheriff's Department Deputy Nate Trujillo said.

"It's mainly growers," Trujillo said. "And a lot of them, they don't want to leave because that is their livelihood."

As many as 1,000 people remained in Post Mountain and Trinity Pines, authorities and local residents estimated Thursday.

Numerous studies in recent years have linked bigger U.S. wildfires to global warming from the burning of coal, oil and gas, especially because climate change has made California much drier. A drier California means plants are more flammable.

The U.S. Forest Service's Pacific Southwest Region announced Friday that it is extending the closure of all nine national forests in California due to concerns including fire conditions and critical limitations on firefighting resources.

The threatened marijuana growing area is in the Emerald Triangle, a three-county corner of Northern California that by some estimates is the nation's largest cannabis-producing region.

People familiar with Trinity Pines said the community has up to 40 legal farms, with more than 10 times that number in hidden, illegal growing areas.

Growers are wary of leaving the plants vulnerable to flames or thieves. Each farm has crops worth half a million dollars or more and many are within days or weeks of harvest.

One estimate put the value of the area's legal marijuana crop at about $20 million.

"There (are) millions of dollars, millions and millions of dollars of marijuana out there," Trujillo said. "Some of those plants are 16 feet (5 metres) tall, and they are all in the budding stages of growth right now."

Gunfire in the region is common. A recent night brought what locals dubbed the "roll call" of cannabis cultivators shooting rounds from pistols and automatic weapons as warnings to outsiders, said Post Mountain volunteer Fire Chief Astrid Dobo, who also manages legal cannabis farms.

Hundreds of migrant workers typically pour into the area this time of year to help trim and harvest the plants, but it's uncertain whether that population dwindled due to the coronavirus pandemic, said Julia Rubinic, a member of the Trinity County Agriculture Alliance, which represents licensed cannabis growers.

Mike McMillan, spokesman for the federal incident command team managing the northern section of the August Complex, said fire officials plan to deliver a clear message that "we are not going to die to save people. That is not our job."

"We are going to knock door to door and tell them once again," McMillan said. "However, if they choose to stay and if the fire situation becomes, as we say, very dynamic and very dangerous ... we are not going to risk our lives."

A firefighter was killed and another was injured on Aug. 31 while working on the fire. Diana Jones, a volunteer firefighter from Texas, was among 26 people who have died since more than two dozen major wildfires broke out across the state last month.

A memorial service was held Friday for a veteran firefighter, Charles Morton, 39, a squad boss with the Big Bear Interagency Hotshot Crew who died Sept. 17 while battling the El Dorado Fire in the San Bernardino National Forest east of Los Angeles.

"I know that Charlie was a very skilled, in fact extraordinary, firefighter and a fire leader," U.S. Forest Service Chief Vicki Christiansen told the gathering at The Rock Church in San Bernardino.

"He committed himself, often for weeks and months on end, to protecting lives, communities and natural resources all around this country in service to fellow Americans."

The Butte County Sheriff's Office on Friday released the identity of another of the 15 people killed in a rampaging forest fire earlier this month. The remains of Linda Longenbach, 71, of Berry Creek, were found on Sept. 10 in a roadway about 10 feet from an ATV, close to the body of a man previously identified as Paul Winer, 68.

A relative told investigators the victims were aware of the fire and chose not to evacuate.

____

Associated Press writer John Antczak in Los Angeles contributed to this report.

urn:contentItem:602S-HB81-DY9S-T05D-00000-00Today in History - June 182020-06-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:24ZLexisNexisNATIONALToday in History - June 18Today in History - June 18The Canadian Press

Today in History for June 18:

On this date:

In 1464, Roman Catholic Pope Pius II organized a crusade against the Turks, but died before he could meet up with his allies. Soon after, the crusading mentality died out.

In 1812, the U.S. declared war on Britain following disputes over Maritime rights. It was the only major war, other than native wars, fought on Canadian soil.

In 1815, deposed French emperor Napoleon Bonaparte was defeated at the Battle of Waterloo by British and Prussian troops.

In 1846, the first telegraph system was opened connecting Toronto, Hamilton and Niagara Falls, Ont.

In 1855, the rebuilding of the Sault Ste. Marie Canal was completed.

In 1873, suffragist Susan B. Anthony was found guilty by a judge in Canandaigua, N.Y., of breaking the law by casting a vote in the 1872 presidential election. The judge fined Anthony $100, but she never paid.

In 1908, parliamentarian Stanley Knowles was born in Los Angeles to Canadian parents. He spent nearly four decades in Parliament, championing the causes of veterans, the elderly, the poor and the disadvantaged. He died in 1997, nine days short of his 89th birthday.

In 1928, Norwegian polar explorer Roald Amundsen died after a flying accident in the North Sea.

In 1940, during the Second World War, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill urged his countrymen to conduct themselves in a manner that would prompt future generations to say, "This was their finest hour."

In 1962, a federal election left the Conservatives under John Diefenbaker with a minority government after they lost 100 seats from their 1958 landslide. The Tories were defeated in both the Commons and a general election the following year.

In 1983, Sally Ride became the first American woman in space as she and four colleagues blasted off aboard the shuttle "Challenger." The mission included the deployment of Canada's "Anik C2" communications satellite.

In 1985, an Ontario election led to the end of 42 years of Conservative rule in the province. David Peterson's Liberals took power through an alliance with the New Democrats.

In 1996, 47-year-old Benjamin Netanyahu was sworn in as Israel's youngest prime minister after he formed a six-party governing coalition.

In 1999, Adam Leboucan became Canada's youngest dangerous offender when a B.C. judge sentenced the 17-year-old to an indefinite prison term for the brutal sexual assault of an infant.

In 2000, Tiger Woods romped to a record 15-stroke victory in the U.S. Open golf championship at Pebble Beach, Calif.

In 2002, a joint U.S.-Canadian military inquiry found that American pilot Maj. Harry Schmidt mistakenly dropped a bomb on Canadian soldiers in Afghanistan, killing four and wounding eight because he did not take time to properly assess the threat.

In 2003, Inuvik-based Aboriginal Pipeline Group signed a landmark deal with Trans-Canada Corp. and four natural gas producers, giving natives in the Northwest Territories one-third ownership of a $5 billion Arctic pipleline project.

In 2008, Ontario joined Quebec in banning the cosmetic use of pesticides across the province.

In 2010, the inquiry report into the death of Robert Dziekanski concluded that RCMP officers were not justified in using their Taser on him at Vancouver's airport in October 2007, and that their explanations of the events that unfolded the night he died were "patently unbelievable."

In 2013, Afghanistan President Hamid Karzai announced Afghan forces took over the lead from the U.S.-led NATO coalition for security nationwide, a significant milestone in the 12-year war.

In 2015, Manitoba became the first province to formally apologize for the '60s Scoop, when child-welfare agents removed aboriginal children from their families and placed them for adoption in non-Indigenous homes. A few days later, Alberta also apologized.

In 2017, 19-year-old Canadian Brooke Henderson won the Meijer LPGA Classic for her fourth LPGA Tour title.

In 2017, Brooks Koepka tied a U.S. Open record at 16-under in capturing his first major title.

In 2017, a raging forest fire in central Portugal sent flames sweeping over roads, killing at least 62 people, many of them trapped in their cars as they tried to flee.

In 2018, Conservative Richard Martel stole the federal Quebec riding of Chicoutimi-Le Fjord from the Liberals in a byelection precipitated by the resignation of rookie MP Denis Lemieux.

In 2019, Justin Trudeau gave Canada's controversial Trans Mountain pipeline expansion a second lease on life. The decision to approve the project a second time comes nine months after the Federal Court of Appeal ripped up the original approval, citing incomplete Indigenous consultations and a faulty environmental review. The decision came the day after the Liberals passed a motion in the House of Commons declaring climate change a national emergency that would require more cuts to emissions than have already been promised. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said he was sympathetic to concerns about the environment and the need to transition to cleaner sources of energy, but Canada needed to take advantage of its natural resources while they are still needed in order to fund that transition.

urn:contentItem:6601-YVN1-JDV5-F01B-00000-00UPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program2021-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:24ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1UPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program


Mississauga's photo radar cameras were activated in summer 2021 and the city's program is expanding. Here are a few things to know about Mississauga's speed cameras, including their locations.

Timeline

Mississauga council approved the city's automated speed enforcement (ASE) program as part of the 2020 budget, with the original launch date planned for September of that year.



City staff said delays related to the COVID-19 pandemic slowed down the roll-out of the program.

In May, Ward 9 Coun. Pat Saito successfully moved a motion to accelerate plans for more speed cameras in the city, boosting the program from two cameras to 22 by the end of the 2021.

The City of Mississauga's first two photo radar cameras became active July 5 last year with units in the Malton and Erin Mills neighbourhoods.

City officials said they planned to activate the remaining 20 speed cameras by the end of 2021.

As of July 20, 2022 17 speed cameras of 22 were activated.

Tickets

City staff estimated in 2020 that 22 photo radar units would generate 160,000 charges annually.

According to a Mississauga press release, 495 speeding tickets came from the first two speed camera locations, Morning Star Drive and Sawmill Valley Drive, which were in place from July 5 to the first week of August 2021.

In an emailed statement, the city's road safety supervisor Colin Patterson wrote that Mississauga's photo-radar cameras issued another 4,827 speeding tickets between August and December of 2021.

As of June 3, the city reported that 8,258 tickets have been issued in total for the program but only around 25 per cent of the associated fines had been paid.

During that time approximately 1,600 additional vehicles were caught speeding by the city's photo-radar units but were not ticketed due in part to a provincial requirement to issue fines within 30 days of the offence.

The City of Mississauga's first two photo radar cameras became active July 5 last year with units in the Malton and Erin Mills neighbourhoods.

City officials said they planned to activate the remaining 20 speed cameras by the end of 2021.

As of July 13, 2022 14 speed cameras of 22 were activated.

Tickets

City staff estimated in 2020 that 22 photo radar units would generate 160,000 charges annually.

According to a Mississauga press release, 495 speeding tickets came from the first two speed camera locations, Morning Star Drive and Sawmill Valley Drive, which were in place from July 5 to the first week of August 2021.

In an emailed statement, the city's road safety supervisor Colin Patterson wrote that Mississauga's photo-radar cameras issued another 4,827 speeding tickets between August and December of 2021.

As of June 3, the city reported that 8,258 tickets have been issued in total for the program but only around 25 per cent of the associated fines had been paid.

During that time approximately 1,600 additional vehicles were caught speeding by the city's photo-radar units but were not ticketed due in part to a provincial requirement to issue fines within 30 days of the offence.

urn:contentItem:6281-YYC1-JDV5-F1X8-00000-00A year into his role as Canadian Tire's CEO, Greg Hicks explains how the company's physical stores aided its huge success in e-commerce during the pandemic2021-03-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:24ZLexisNexisBUSINESSA year into his role as Canadian Tire's CEO, Greg Hicks explains how the company's physical stores aided its huge success in e-commerce during the pandemicJoanna Pachner

Canadian Tire's status as this country's general store has stood it in good stead during the pandemic: while you're stocking up on hockey pucks, you can also grab a baking pan and socks for your son, top up on hand sanitizer and get some gas, all in one shopping trip. Even the moniker "Crappy Tire" tends to be used affectionately. Yet behind the scenes, the folksy chain has undergone a rapid transformation into a tech-forward, digital analytics-driven omnichannel powerhouse whose sales last year soared by 18 per cent, including a nearly 200 per cent spike in e-commerce. Greg Hicks admits this is not what he expected when he took the company's helm literally on the eve of the largest retail disruption in living memory.

It's almost exactly the one-year mark of your tenure as CEO, so happy anniversary.

Yeah. Seems like five years.

When did you realize this was going to be a year like no other?

The night before the CEO announcement the NBA cancelled the season and the day after the WHO declared a global pandemic. But at that point we were somewhat naive as to the severity of the situation. A couple days later, we were closing the offices and five days later we were shutting more than 1,000 stores. We played defence for six months where you're just reacting.

How did you mobilize? Did you have war rooms to manage the response?

We had an enterprise risk committee in place that would usually deal with isolated disasters like a flood or forest fire and there is a playbook you can pull out. In three days we realized that was not going to work, so we expanded the "nerve centre" to the top 35 or 40 leaders and for months we were meeting multiple times a day. In the early days, the head of the risk committee was playing point on required decisions and we literally knocked them down like dominoes one by one.

Despite all that, you've had an outstanding year, largely by effectively tapping e-commerce. That was a channel where you had long lagged other retailers.

We were in the process of methodical investment in our websites. Having demand accelerate the way it did certainly caught us by surprise and we had our share of hiccups, but the foundation we were building enabled us to respond quickly. First, we chose which parts of the website to own versus partner on. Sounds like a simple idea but those were critical decisions. We had been a build-from-within organization for a long time, but we brought in a new site search partner, a product recommendations engine and a site personalization engine. Second, we invested heavily in the Triangle [rewards program] and Canadian Tire app. Finally, and this one was key, we in-sourced in late 2019 our digital marketing capability, creating a centralized team of experts.

Our physical store reach also helped us thrive. Those assets are often overlooked when thinking about readiness for battle in e-commerce. But think of it this way: We had 22 million square feet of warehouse space that sits within a 10-minute drive of 90 per cent of Canadians, and those warehouses happen to have 25 million square feet of product showrooms attached to them where you can walk out with the product that day.

Wait: you think of your stores as showrooms now?

Traditionally no, but we're trying to find a way to explain why people shouldn't be surprised that we continue to thrive. The pandemic has solidified the fact that the physical store is absolutely critical. It allows us to present and merchandise inspiration in a way an online pure play can't, and it can be the epicentre of fulfilment. Whether we knew it or not, we've been getting ready for this consumer shift for a year. We're a much more digital company than we were 12 months ago.

What lessons from this past year are you going to take into the future?

The biggest is how powerful it is to embrace progress over perfection. In crisis management, there just isn't time for the meeting before the meeting and the meeting after meeting, the hierarchies, the egos. The workplace is another obvious place to talk about. Flexibility is the new F word, and flexibility about where people work is here to stay. The next big adjustment will involve technology. No longer will technology be viewed as a separate function. Virtually every company is now a technology company.

Canadian Tire owns other retail banners, including SportChek, Mark's, Pro Hockey Life. One that's puzzling is Party City. How does that fit in?

I've gotten that perplexed question before. This is the first time customer data shaped our acquisition target. The data from our Triangle program and credit card business showed us that Party City's customers skewed young and spent 60 per cent more at Canadian Tire than our average Triangle member. Party City has a small footprint in Canada but the people who live in those markets, who have our credit card, who are members of our program, can earn and redeem Canadian Tire money, and that kind of earn-and-burn cycle helps drive a flywheel of loyalty to the entire ecosystem.

In retail, experience and gut have long ruled decision making. How do you strike the balance between that human acumen and data analytics?

A big chunk of my career was on the merchant side and there's a lot of intuition there. Now, "I think" is diminishing in our vocabulary and moving to "I know" because we have so much data and there is little room for subjectivity. Few meaningful decision-making protocols don't still have a mix of art and science, but some we once thought were exclusively art, like margin management, have surprised even the most devoutly old-school merchants. What I love about empirical data is that it can snap a debate into focus, as when a dealer is wondering whether they should take a deeper position in a certain category.

You have deep personal roots in that dealer network.

Yes. My father was an officer of the company and went on to become a dealer. I had two uncles who were dealers and I worked in my dad's store. We had this cubbyhole underneath his office where you mixed paint for customers and he showed me how to use the machine and 10 minutes later I was working the paint aisle. I was maybe 15.

You've compared running Canadian Tire to nation building. The chain may be a fixture, but is that a stretch?

Canada is just over 150 years old and we will celebrate our 100-year anniversary next year, so in a way we grew up with Canada. The way our history and values evolved have largely reflected Canadian values that are so different from our neighbours to the south and one substantial difference is the value we place on community over individual.

Many people have gizmos that they never thought existed or they needed until they spotted them at Canadian Tire. What's your favourite?

Oh, I love the little Noma humidifiers that sit on your desk. When I'm on hockey road trips with the kids or sleeping in hotels, I take them with me. Every house should have 10.

(This has been edited for length and clarity.)

Joanna Pachner is a business writer and a freelance contributor for the Star.

Mississauga's photo radar cameras were activated in summer 2021 and the city's program is expanding. Here are a few things to know about Mississauga's speed cameras, including their locations.

Timeline

Mississauga council approved the city's automated speed enforcement (ASE) program as part of the 2020 budget, with the original launch date planned for September of that year.



City staff said delays related to the COVID-19 pandemic slowed down the roll-out of the program.

In May, Ward 9 Coun. Pat Saito successfully moved a motion to accelerate plans for more speed cameras in the city, boosting the program from two cameras to 22 by the end of the 2021.

The City of Mississauga's first two photo radar cameras became active July 5 last year with units in the Malton and Erin Mills neighbourhoods.

City officials said they planned to activate the remaining 20 speed cameras by the end of 2021.

As of Monday, Nov. 21, 20 speed cameras of 22 were activated.

Tickets

City staff estimated in 2020 that 22 photo radar units would generate 160,000 charges annually.

According to a Mississauga press release, 495 speeding tickets came from the first two speed camera locations, Morning Star Drive and Sawmill Valley Drive, which were in place from July 5 to the first week of August 2021.

In an emailed statement, the city's road safety supervisor Colin Patterson wrote that Mississauga's photo-radar cameras issued another 4,827 speeding tickets between August and December of 2021.

As of June 3, the city reported that 8,258 tickets have been issued in total for the program but only around 25 per cent of the associated fines had been paid.

During that time approximately 1,600 additional vehicles were caught speeding by the city's photo-radar units but were not ticketed due in part to a provincial requirement to issue fines within 30 days of the offence.

urn:contentItem:65Y6-0FS1-JDV5-F202-00000-00UPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program2021-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:24ZLexisNexisNEWSUPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program

Mississauga's photo radar cameras were activated in summer 2021 and the city's program is expanding. Here are a few things to know about Mississauga's speed cameras, including their locations.

Timeline

Mississauga council approved the city's automated speed enforcement (ASE) program as part of the 2020 budget, with the original launch date planned for September of that year.

City staff said delays related to the COVID-19 pandemic slowed down the roll-out of the program.

In May, Ward 9 Coun. Pat Saito successfully moved a motion to accelerate plans for more speed cameras in the city, boosting the program from two cameras to 22 by the end of the 2021.

The City of Mississauga's first two photo radar cameras became active July 5 last year with units in the Malton and Erin Mills neighbourhoods.

City officials said they planned to activate the remaining 20 speed cameras by the end of 2021.

As of July 15, 2022 15 speed cameras of 22 were activated.

Tickets

City staff estimated in 2020 that 22 photo radar units would generate 160,000 charges annually.

According to a Mississauga press release, 495 speeding tickets came from the first two speed camera locations, Morning Star Drive and Sawmill Valley Drive, which were in place from July 5 to the first week of August 2021.

In an emailed statement, the city's road safety supervisor Colin Patterson wrote that Mississauga's photo-radar cameras issued another 4,827 speeding tickets between August and December of 2021.

As of June 3, the city reported that 8,258 tickets have been issued in total for the program but only around 25 per cent of the associated fines had been paid.

During that time approximately 1,600 additional vehicles were caught speeding by the city's photo-radar units but were not ticketed due in part to a provincial requirement to issue fines within 30 days of the offence.

urn:contentItem:65XJ-5GH1-F197-51F5-00000-00UPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program2021-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:24ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1UPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program


Mississauga's photo radar cameras were activated in summer 2021 and the city's program is expanding. Here are a few things to know about Mississauga's speed cameras, including their locations.

Timeline

Mississauga council approved the city's automated speed enforcement (ASE) program as part of the 2020 budget, with the original launch date planned for September of that year.



City staff said delays related to the COVID-19 pandemic slowed down the roll-out of the program.

In May, Ward 9 Coun. Pat Saito successfully moved a motion to accelerate plans for more speed cameras in the city, boosting the program from two cameras to 22 by the end of the 2021.

The City of Mississauga's first two photo radar cameras became active July 5 last year with units in the Malton and Erin Mills neighbourhoods.

City officials said they planned to activate the remaining 20 speed cameras by the end of 2021.

As of July 13, 2022 14 speed cameras of 22 were activated.

Tickets

City staff estimated in 2020 that 22 photo radar units would generate 160,000 charges annually.

According to a Mississauga press release, 495 speeding tickets came from the first two speed camera locations, Morning Star Drive and Sawmill Valley Drive, which were in place from July 5 to the first week of August 2021.

In an emailed statement, the city's road safety supervisor Colin Patterson wrote that Mississauga's photo-radar cameras issued another 4,827 speeding tickets between August and December of 2021.

As of June 3, the city reported that 8,258 tickets have been issued in total for the program but only around 25 per cent of the associated fines had been paid.

During that time approximately 1,600 additional vehicles were caught speeding by the city's photo-radar units but were not ticketed due in part to a provincial requirement to issue fines within 30 days of the offence.

urn:contentItem:66TM-RCJ1-JDV5-F42R-00000-00UPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program2021-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:24ZLexisNexisNEWSUPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program

Mississauga's photo radar cameras were activated in summer 2021 and the city's program is expanding. Here are a few things to know about Mississauga's speed cameras, including their locations.

Timeline

Mississauga council approved the city's automated speed enforcement (ASE) program as part of the 2020 budget, with the original launch date planned for September of that year.

City staff said delays related to the COVID-19 pandemic slowed down the roll-out of the program.

In May, Ward 9 Coun. Pat Saito successfully moved a motion to accelerate plans for more speed cameras in the city, boosting the program from two cameras to 22 by the end of the 2021.

The City of Mississauga's first two photo radar cameras became active July 5 last year with units in the Malton and Erin Mills neighbourhoods.

City officials said they planned to activate the remaining 20 speed cameras by the end of 2021.

As of Monday, Nov. 7, 22 speed cameras of 22 were activated or would be active shortly.

Tickets

City staff estimated in 2020 that 22 photo radar units would generate 160,000 charges annually.

According to a Mississauga press release, 495 speeding tickets came from the first two speed camera locations, Morning Star Drive and Sawmill Valley Drive, which were in place from July 5 to the first week of August 2021.

In an emailed statement, the city's road safety supervisor Colin Patterson wrote that Mississauga's photo-radar cameras issued another 4,827 speeding tickets between August and December of 2021.

As of June 3, the city reported that 8,258 tickets have been issued in total for the program but only around 25 per cent of the associated fines had been paid.

During that time approximately 1,600 additional vehicles were caught speeding by the city's photo-radar units but were not ticketed due in part to a provincial requirement to issue fines within 30 days of the offence.

urn:contentItem:65WG-9JS1-JDV5-F3RN-00000-00UPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program2021-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:24ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1UPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program


Mississauga's photo radar cameras were activated in summer 2021 and the city's program is expanding. Here are a few things to know about Mississauga's speed cameras, including their locations.

Timeline

Mississauga council approved the city's automated speed enforcement (ASE) program as part of the 2020 budget, with the original launch date planned for September of that year.



City staff said delays related to the COVID-19 pandemic slowed down the roll-out of the program.

In May, Ward 9 Coun. Pat Saito successfully moved a motion to accelerate plans for more speed cameras in the city, boosting the program from two cameras to 22 by the end of the 2021.

The City of Mississauga's first two photo radar cameras became active July 5 last year with units in the Malton and Erin Mills neighbourhoods.

City officials said they planned to activate the remaining 20 speed cameras by the end of 2021.

As of July 8, 2022 15 speed cameras of 22 were activated.

Tickets

City staff estimated in 2020 that 22 photo radar units would generate 160,000 charges annually.

According to a Mississauga press release, 495 speeding tickets came from the first two speed camera locations, Morning Star Drive and Sawmill Valley Drive, which were in place from July 5 to the first week of August 2021.

In an emailed statement, the city's road safety supervisor Colin Patterson wrote that Mississauga's photo-radar cameras issued another 4,827 speeding tickets between August and December of 2021.

As of June 3, the city reported that 8,258 tickets have been issued in total for the program but only around 25 per cent of the associated fines had been paid.

During that time approximately 1,600 additional vehicles were caught speeding by the city's photo-radar units but were not ticketed due in part to a provincial requirement to issue fines within 30 days of the offence.
